question: 13, years old boy, LEAST common cause of proximal lytic lesion of head of femur is:
exp: Ans. is 'a' Plasmacytoma If multiple myeloma occurs as a solitary lesion it is K/a Plasmacytoma. Age gp is 6th-7th decade, Rare before 40yrs of age. So the lytic lesion in a 13yrs old boy cannot be a plasmacytoma

question: Most common soft tissue tumor in a child:
exp: (a) Rhabdomyosarcoma- Rhabdomyosarcoma, the most common childhood soft-tissue sarcoma, is often located in the head and neck (40%) and in the trunk and extremities (25%).

question: Most sensitive test for skeletal metastasis is
exp: A. i. e. (Radio-isotope) (20 - Apley 8th)* The best indication for a bone scan is suspected multiple bony lesions such as in metastatic carcinoma an lymphoma of bone (302 - current diagnosis & Treatment - orthopedics)* Most common imaging agents are technetium 99 m and indium 111* Tc99m used to assess the degree of osteoblastic activity* Tc99m scan are also useful in distinguishing blastic lesions of bone* Isotope scaning is also used in the staging process of a primary sarcoma such as an osteosarcoma to make sure the patient does not have an asymptomatic remote skeletal lesions

question: A classical expansile lytic lesion in the transverse process of a vertebra is seen in:
exp: (b) Aneurysmal bone cyst. Lytic Lesion in Posterior Element of Vertebrae (i. e. spinous process, transverse process, and pedicle) Expansile and Purely lytic, Aneurysmal Bone Cyst, Non-expansile and partly or extensively ossified, Osteoblastoma Body of vertebra is involved in GCT

question: Most common site of metastases in case of osteosarcoma is
exp: Ans. is 'b' i. e., Lungs * Almost 10% of the patient have metastases at presentation. Metastases is most common to lungs, but hematogenous spread to other organs is also possible - including lymph nodes, brain and skeleton.
